sn44.1:1.1: The “undeclared points” are a stock series of propositions typically raised by non-Buddhists. It seems they formed a kind of scheme for evaluating and positioning different philosophies, which were assumed to answer them definitively. They are discussed many times in the Suttas, eg. SN 16.12, SN 24.15–18, SN 33.1–55.
sn44.1:1.2: Khemā was extolled as the foremost nun in great wisdom (AN 1.236); her verses are at Thig 6.3; see SN 17.24:1.7. | Toraṇavatthu (“the site of the arch”) appears only here.
sn44.1:1.5: Pasenadi uses the default masculine forms, the significance of which becomes apparent below.
sn44.1:3.5: Pasenadi was used to having philosophical conversations with his wife, Queen Mallikā (SN 3.8:1.2).
sn44.1:4.1: The king bows to the nun, just as he would to the Buddha.
sn44.1:4.2: That is, an awakened one, whether the Buddha or anyone else, exists after death, for example in heaven or an eternal state of Nirvana. | Here “realized one” (tathāgata) pertains to any arahant, as at SN 54.12. The Pali commentary says that a “living being” (satta) is meant. However, tathāgata and satta are exact verbal parallels: tathā (“real”) + gata (“come to the state of”) and sa (“real”) + tta (“state of”). Thus it seems likely that this was originally intended as a mere verbal gloss to explain the compound. That it does not mean just any sentient being is established at SN 22.86:1.5.
sn44.1:4.5: A sage ceases to exist at the time of death. This assumes there is an enduring “self” that is done away with.
sn44.1:4.8: This kind of “both A and not A” statements are not meant to be paradoxical or mystical. Rather, they represent some state that combines elements of both. For example, their body does not exist but their mind does.
sn44.1:4.11: Likewise, “neither A nor not A” is not meant to be a paradox, but to indicate something that cannot be characterized by the original term. For example, a sage persists after death in a subtle state that is not what we normally consider existence.
sn44.1:6.3: Accountant (gaṇaka), finger-tallier (muddika), and reckoner (saṅkhāyako) are terms for the job that used to be called “computer”.
sn44.1:13.2: Text has virodhayissati (“contradict”), wheras AN 11.7:10.2 has variant viggayhissati (“conflict”).
